title: Family on vacation in South Carolina discover package containing 44 pounds of cocaine
text:
A family have pulled a package containing 44 pounds (20 kilograms) of cocaine from the Atlantic Ocean during a vacation in South Carolina.

The clan were taking a stroll along the waters of Fripp Island on Sunday evening when they spotted a large package floating in the waves close to shore.

Beaufort County Sheriff's Office say the family dragged the parcel from the water and hauled it onto their golf cart before transporting it back to their nearby vacation home.

The holidaymakers were left stunned when they later sliced open the package and discovered 20 bricks of white powder.

They promptly called police, who confirmed the substance was cocaine.

A family have pulled 44 pounds (20 kilograms) of cocaine from the Atlantic Ocean during a vacation in South Carolina. A stock image is pictured

Bob Bromage of the Beaufort County Sheriff's Office says his department 'conservatively' estimate the package has a street value of $600,000.

He says a kilo of the drug is currently valued at around $30,000.

'This is a major weight of cocaine,' he told The State.

Bromage says it's rare for narcotics to turn up in Beaufort County, although the area was a hotbed for drug smugglers in the late '70s and early '80s, according to The State.

The family were on vacation in Fripp Island in Beaufort County (pictured)

That lead to a large-scale federal investigation known as Operation Jackpot, which saw more than 100 people arrested and convicted for drug offences.

Investigators are now trying to determine the origins of Sunday's Fripp Island find, but they believe it may have washed ashore after Hurricane Dorian.

It wouldn't be the only package of drugs to reach land following that weather event in August.

33 pounds (15 kilos) of cocaine washed up on Cocoa Beach, Florida, last month in the aftermath of the hurricane.

The drugs were stuffed in a duffel bag.

Meanwhile, a single brick of cocaine was also discovered by a beach-goer in Melbourne following the hurricane.

The package was heavily wrapped and was quickly reported to police.
